pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:0.5.eng: 25. The training rule on taking back a robe

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.1.pli: Tena samayena buddho bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.1.eng: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā upanando sakyaputto bhātuno saddhivihārikaṃ bhikkhuṃ etadavoca—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.2.eng: Venerable Upananda the Sakyan said to his brother’s student,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.7.eng: And he gave him a robe.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.9.eng: that the Buddha was about to go wandering the country.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.11.pli: “na dānāhaṃ āyasmatā upanandena sakyaputtena saddhiṃ janapadacārikaṃ pakkamissāmi, bhagavatā saddhiṃ janapadacārikaṃ pakkamissāmī”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.11.eng: “Now I’ll go wandering with the Buddha instead.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.12.pli: Atha kho āyasmā upanando sakyaputto taṃ bhikkhuṃ etadavoca—

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.14.pli: “Nāhaṃ, bhante, tayā saddhiṃ janapadacārikaṃ pakkamissāmi, bhagavatā saddhiṃ janapadacārikaṃ pakkamissāmī”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.14.eng: he replied, “I’m not going with you, but with the Buddha.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.15.pli: “Yampi tyāhaṃ, āvuso, cīvaraṃ adāsiṃ, mayā saddhiṃ janapadacārikaṃ pakkamissatī”ti,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.15.eng: “Well, that robe I gave you is going with me,”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.16.eng: and he just took it back in anger.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.17.pli: Atha kho so bhikkhu bhikkhūnaṃ etamatthaṃ ārocesi.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.17.eng: That monk told other monks what had happened.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.18.pli: Ye te bhikkhū appicchā …pe… te ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.18.eng: And the monks of few desires complained and criticized Upananda,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.19.pli: “kathañhi nāma āyasmā upanando sakyaputto bhikkhussa sāmaṃ cīvaraṃ datvā kupito anattamano acchindissatī”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.19.eng: “How could Venerable Upananda give away a robe and then take it back in anger?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.20.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū āyasmantaṃ upanandaṃ sakyaputtaṃ anekapariyāyena vigarahitvā bhagavato etamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ …pe…
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.20.eng: After rebuking him in many ways, they told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.21.pli: “saccaṃ kira tvaṃ, upananda, bhikkhussa sāmaṃ cīvaraṃ datvā kupito anattamano acchindī”ti?
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.21.eng: “Is it true, Upananda, that you did this?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.24.pli: kathañhi nāma tvaṃ, moghapurisa, bhikkhussa sāmaṃ cīvaraṃ datvā kupito anattamano acchindissasi.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.24.eng: “Foolish man, how could you do this?

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.26.pli: evañca pana, bhikkhave, imaṃ sikkhāpadaṃ uddiseyyātha—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.26.eng: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.27.1.pli: “Yo pana bhikkhu bhikkhussa sāmaṃ cīvaraṃ datvā kupito anattamano acchindeyya vā acchindāpeyya vā, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyan”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:1.27.1.eng: ‘If a monk himself gives a robe to a monk, but then, in anger, takes it back or has it taken back, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.’”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.4.eng: … The monk who has been given the full ordination by a unanimous Sangha through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.10.pli: channaṃ cīvarānaṃ aññataraṃ cīvaraṃ, vikappanupagaṃ pacchimaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.10.eng: one of the six kinds of robe-cloth, but not smaller than what can be assigned to another.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.10.comm: The six are linen, cotton, silk, wool, sunn hemp, and hemp; see Kd 8:3.1.6. According to Kd 8:21.1.4, the size referred to here is no smaller than 8 by 4 sugataṅgula, “standard fingerbreadths”. For an explanation of the idea of vikappanā, see Appendix of Technical Terms. For the rendering of cīvara as “robe-cloth”, see the same appendix.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.14.eng: if he takes it back himself, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.16.eng: if he asks another, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.17.pli: Sakiṃ āṇatto bahukampi acchindati, nissaggiyaṃ hoti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.17.eng: If he only asks once, then even if the other takes back many, it becomes subject to relinquishment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.17.comm: “Many” renders bahukaṁ. Sp 1.633: Āṇatto bahūni gaṇhāti, ekaṁ pācittiyaṁ, “If the one who is asked takes many, there is (only) one offense entailing confession.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.18.pli: Nissajjitabbaṃ saṅghassa vā gaṇassa vā puggalassa vā.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.18.eng: The robe-cloth should be relinquished to a sangha, a group, or an individual.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.19.eng: “And, monks, it should be relinquished like this.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.20.eng: (To be expanded as in Bu NP 1:3.2.5–3.2.29, with appropriate substitutions.)

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.21.pli: “idaṃ me, bhante, cīvaraṃ bhikkhussa sāmaṃ datvā acchinnaṃ nissaggiyaṃ imāhaṃ saṅghassa nissajjāmī”ti …pe…
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.21.eng: ‘Venerables, this robe-cloth, which I took back after giving it to a monk, is to be relinquished. I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ …

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.24.eng: ‘I give this robe-cloth back to you.’”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.25.1.pli: Upasampanne upasampannasaññī cīvaraṃ datvā kupito anattamano acchindati vā acchindāpeti vā, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.25.1.eng: If the other person is fully ordained and he perceives them as such, and after giving them robe-cloth, he takes it back in anger or has it taken back, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.26.pli: Upasampanne vematiko cīvaraṃ datvā kupito anattamano acchindati vā acchindāpeti vā, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.26.eng: If the other person is fully ordained, but he is unsure of it, and after giving them robe-cloth, he takes it back in anger or has it taken back, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.27.pli: Upasampanne anupasampannasaññī cīvaraṃ datvā kupito anattamano acchindati vā acchindāpeti vā, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.27.eng: If the other person is fully ordained, but he does not perceive them as such, and after giving them robe-cloth, he takes it back in anger or has it taken back, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.28.pli: Aññaṃ parikkhāraṃ datvā kupito anattamano acchindati vā acchindāpeti vā, āpatti dukkaṭassa.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.28.eng: If, after giving them another requisite, he takes it back in anger or has it taken back, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.29.pli: Anupasampannassa cīvaraṃ vā aññaṃ vā parikkhāraṃ datvā kupito anattamano acchindati vā acchindāpeti vā, āpatti dukkaṭassa.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.29.eng: If, after giving robe-cloth or another requisite to a person who is not fully ordained, he takes it back in anger or has it taken back, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.30.eng: If the other person is not fully ordained, but he perceives them as such, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.31.eng: If the other person is not fully ordained, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.32.eng: If the other person is not fully ordained, and he does not perceive them as such, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.34.eng: if the other person gives it back;

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.35.eng: if he takes it on trust from them;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.35.comm: This refers to a situation where you have an agreement with a close friend that you may take their belongings on trust. The conditions for taking on trust are set out at Kd 8:19.1.5.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.37.eng: if he is the first offender.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np25:2.38.eng: The training rule on taking back a robe, the fifth, is finished.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:0.5.eng: 26. The training rule on asking for thread

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.1.pli: Tena samayena buddho bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.1.eng: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Rājagaha in the Bamboo Grove,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū cīvarakārasamaye bahuṃ suttaṃ viññāpesuṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.2.eng: the monks from the group of six were making robes and they asked for a large amount of thread.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.2.comm: From the origin story to Bu Pc 32 it seems cīvarakārasamaya refers to any time one is making a robe, see Bu Pc 32:9.1.10.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.3.pli: Katepi cīvare bahuṃ suttaṃ avasiṭṭhaṃ hoti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.3.eng: But when their robes were finished, there was much thread left over.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.5.pli: “handa mayaṃ, āvuso, aññampi suttaṃ viññāpetvā tantavāyehi cīvaraṃ vāyāpemā”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.5.eng: “Well, let’s ask for even more thread and get weavers to weave us robe-cloth.”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.6.pli: Atha kho chabbaggiyā bhikkhū aññampi suttaṃ viññāpetvā tantavāyehi cīvaraṃ vāyāpesuṃ.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.7.pli: Vītepi cīvare bahuṃ suttaṃ avasiṭṭhaṃ hoti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.7.eng: Yet even when that robe-cloth had been woven, there was much thread left over.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.8.pli: Dutiyampi kho chabbaggiyā bhikkhū aññampi suttaṃ viññāpetvā tantavāyehi cīvaraṃ vāyāpesuṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.8.eng: A second time they asked for more thread and had weavers weave them robe-cloth.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.9.pli: Vītepi cīvare bahuṃ suttaṃ avasiṭṭhaṃ hoti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.9.eng: Once again there was much thread left over.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.10.pli: Tatiyampi kho chabbaggiyā bhikkhū aññampi suttaṃ viññāpetvā tantavāyehi cīvaraṃ vāyāpesuṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.10.eng: A third time they asked for more thread and had weavers weave them robe-cloth.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.12.pli: “kathañhi nāma samaṇā sakyaputtiyā sāmaṃ suttaṃ viññāpetvā tantavāyehi cīvaraṃ vāyāpessantī”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.12.eng: “How could the Sakyan monastics ask for thread and then get weavers to weave them robe-cloth?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.13.pli: Assosuṃ kho bhikkhū tesaṃ manussānaṃ ujjhāyantānaṃ khiyyantānaṃ vipācentānaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.13.eng: The monks heard the complaints of those people,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.14.pli: Ye te bhikkhū appicchā …pe… te ujjhāyanti khiyyanti vipācenti—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.14.eng: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized those monks,

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.15.pli: “kathañhi nāma chabbaggiyā bhikkhū sāmaṃ suttaṃ viññāpetvā tantavāyehi cīvaraṃ vāyāpessantī”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.15.eng: “How could the monks from the group of six ask for thread and then get weavers to weave them robe-cloth?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.16.pli: Atha kho te bhikkhū chabbaggiye bhikkhū anekapariyāyena vigarahitvā bhagavato etamatthaṃ ārocesuṃ …pe…
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.16.eng: After rebuking those monks in many ways, they told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned those monks:

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.17.pli: “saccaṃ kira tumhe, bhikkhave, sāmaṃ suttaṃ viññāpetvā tantavāyehi cīvaraṃ vāyāpethā”ti?
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.17.eng: “Is it true, monks, that you did this?”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.20.pli: kathañhi nāma tumhe, moghapurisā, sāmaṃ suttaṃ viññāpetvā tantavāyehi cīvaraṃ vāyāpessatha.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.20.eng: “Foolish men, how could you do this?

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.22.pli: evañca pana, bhikkhave, imaṃ sikkhāpadaṃ uddiseyyātha—
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.22.eng: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.23.1.pli: “Yo pana bhikkhu sāmaṃ suttaṃ viññāpetvā tantavāyehi cīvaraṃ vāyāpeyya, nissaggiyaṃ pācittiyan”ti.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:1.23.1.eng: ‘If a monk himself asks for thread, and then has weavers weave him robe-cloth, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.’”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.4.eng: … The monk who has been given the full ordination by a unanimous Sangha through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.8.eng: there are six kinds of thread:

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.9.pli: khomaṃ kappāsikaṃ koseyyaṃ kambalaṃ sāṇaṃ bhaṅgaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.9.eng: linen, cotton, silk, wool, sunn hemp, and hemp.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.9.comm: Sp 1.636: Sāṇanti sāṇavākasuttaṁ. Bhaṅganti pāṭekkaṁ vākasuttamevāti eke. Etehi pañcahi missetvā katasuttaṁ pana “bhaṅga”nti veditabbaṁ, “Sāṇa: thread from the bark of hemp. Bhaṅga: some say it is just a separate thread from bark. But bhaṅga is to be understood as the thread made by mixing the (other) five.” SED says: “śaṇa, m. (L. also n.) a kind of hemp, Cannabis Sativa or Crotolaria Juncea …” And: “bhāṅga, mf(ī)n, (fr. bhaṅgā) hempen, made or consisting of hemp …” and “Bhaṅgā, f. hemp (Cannabis Sativa); an intoxicating beverage (or narcotic drug commonly called ‘bhang’) prepared from the hemp plant”. Since SED identifies bhaṅga with Cannabis sativa, I take sāṇa to be Crotolaria juncea, otherwise known as “sunn hemp”.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.11.eng: if he has it woven by weavers, then for every effort there is an act of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.12.eng: When he gets the robe-cloth, it becomes subject to relinquishment.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.13.pli: Nissajjitabbaṃ saṅghassa vā gaṇassa vā puggalassa vā.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.13.eng: The robe-cloth should be relinquished to a sangha, a group, or an individual.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.14.eng: “And, monks, it should be relinquished like this.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.15.eng: (To be expanded as in Bu NP 1:3.2.5–3.2.29, with appropriate substitutions.)

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.16.pli: “idaṃ me, bhante, cīvaraṃ sāmaṃ suttaṃ viññāpetvā tantavāyehi vāyāpitaṃ nissaggiyaṃ.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.16.eng: ‘Venerables, this robe-cloth, which I got weavers to weave after asking for the thread myself, is to be relinquished.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.17.eng: I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ …

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.20.eng: ‘I give this robe-cloth back to you.’”

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.21.1.eng: If he had it woven, and he perceives that he did, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.22.eng: If he had it woven, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.23.eng: If he had it woven, but he does not perceive that he did, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.24.eng: If he did not have it woven, but he perceives that he did, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.25.eng: If he did not have it woven, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.26.eng: If he did not have it woven, and he does not perceive that he did, there is no offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.28.eng: if it is to sew a robe;

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.29.eng: if it is for a back-and-knee strap;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.29.comm: The āyoga is used as a support for the pallattikā sitting posture. See Bhikkhu Ñāṇatusita, “Analysis of the Bhikkhu Pātimokkha”, p. 259, (re. Bu Sk 26:1.3.1).

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.30.eng: if it is for a belt;

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.31.eng: if it is for a shoulder strap;

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.32.eng: if it is for a bowl bag;

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.33.eng: if it is for a water filter;

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.35.eng: if it is from those who have given an invitation;

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.36.eng: if it for the benefit of someone else;

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.37.eng: if it is by means of one’s own property;

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.39.eng: if he is the first offender.

pli-tv-bu-vb-np26:2.40.eng: The training rule on asking for thread, the sixth, is finished.
